sections.title: Our Constitution
sections.content_md:
The Constitution of India came into effect on **26th January 1950**, when India became a **Sovereign Democratic Republic**.

The principles of the Constitution distinguish a constitutional or democratic government from an absolute monarchy or a dictatorship.

sections.title: Definition of Constitution - date of adoption, date of enforcement and its significance.
sections.content_md:
**Definition:** A **Constitution** is a comprehensive document containing the set of rules that describe the rights and duties of its citizens and the manner according to which the governance of a country is to be carried out.

**Significance of the Constitution:**
*   It regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the government: the **legislative**, the **executive**, and the **judiciary**, and states how they are inter-related.
*   It moderates relations between the government and the governed.
*   It protects the interests of the citizens by restraining the government from taking arbitrary decisions.
*   The aim of a Constitution is to ensure smooth governance for the welfare of its citizens.

**Key Dates:**
*   **Date of Adoption:** The Constitution was adopted and passed by the Constituent Assembly on **November 26, 1949**.
*   **Date of Enforcement:** The Constitution as a whole came into force with effect from **January 26, 1950**.

sections.title: ENACTMENT OF THE INDIAN CONSTITUTION
sections.content_md:
The **Cabinet Mission** arrived in India in 1946 and proposed the setting up of a **Constituent Assembly**.

*   Members of the Constituent Assembly were to be elected indirectly by the **Provincial Legislative Assemblies** (Lower House only).
*   Elections to the Provincial Assembly were completed by **July 1946**.
*   The **Princely States** were represented by members nominated by the rulers of these States.
*   The Constituent Assembly of undivided India consisted of **389 members**:
    *   **292** elected from provinces.
    *   **93** nominated by the Princely states.
    *   **3** from Chief Commissioner Provinces.
    *   **1** from the British province of Balochistan.

The Constitution of India was framed by this Constituent Assembly.

sections.title: FORMATION OF THE CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY
sections.content_md:
[Image: Dr. Rajendra Prasad signing the Constitution]

*   The first sitting of the Constituent Assembly was held on **December 9, 1946**, at the present Central Hall of the Parliament.
*   It was presided over by **Dr. Sachidananda Sinha**, the oldest sitting member.
*   On **December 11, 1946**, **Dr. Rajendra Prasad** was elected President of the Constituent Assembly.
*   The **Muslim League boycotted** the Assembly, demanding a separate state of Pakistan. Consequently, members representing territories that went to Pakistan withdrew from the Assembly.
*   The membership of the Constituent Assembly of India was reduced to **299** from the original 389. Of these, **284** members were present on November 26, 1949, to sign the finally passed Constitution.
*   Between December 9, 1946, and August 14, 1947, the Assembly held five sessions.

sections.title: COMPOSITION OF THE CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY
sections.content_md:
The membership of the Constituent Assembly gave representation to all shades of public opinion, making it truly national in character.

*   The Cabinet Mission plan ensured representation for three categories: the **General category, Muslims, and Sikhs**.
*   Congress leaders ensured that other communities also got representation, including **Anglo-Indians, Indian Christians, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes**.

**Notable Representatives:**
*   **Anglo-Indians:** Mr. Frank Anthony and Mr. S.H. Prater.
*   **Indian Christians:** Dr. H.C. Mukherjee and Joseph D'souza.
*   **Parsees:** Dr. H.P. Modi.
*   **Muslims** (who remained after the boycott): Zafar Imam and Mohammad Saadullah.
*   **Sikhs:** Sardar Hukum Singh and Ujjal Singh.

sections.title: Objectives Resolution
sections.content_md:
[Image: Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru]

On **December 13, 1946**, **Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru** proposed the 'Objectives Resolution', which highlighted the objectives and laid down the 'national goals'.

**Key Goals of the Resolution:**
1.  Free India will be nothing but a '**republic**'.
2.  The ideals of **social, political, and economic democracy** would be guaranteed to all people.
3.  The republic would grant **Fundamental Rights** to citizens.
4.  The state would safeguard the rights of **minorities and backward classes**.

The 'Objectives Resolution' was passed by the Constituent Assembly on **January 22, 1947**.

sections.title: DRAFTING COMMITTEE
sections.content_md:
The **Indian Independence Act, 1947**, recognised the Constituent Assembly of India, giving it legal sanction to function as a sovereign body after independence.

The Assembly appointed eight committees to carry on its work.

*   The **Drafting Committee** was set up on **August 29, 1947**.
*   **Dr. B.R. Ambedkar** was its Chairman.
*   The committee was entrusted with the task of drafting the Constitution.
*   The first draft was completed in February 1948.

sections.title: DR. AMBEDKAR'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE INDIAN CONSTITUTION
sections.content_md:
[Image: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar]

Dr. Bhimrao Ambedkar, known as **Babasaheb**, was a key architect of the Constitution. An eminent jurist, economist, politician, and social reformer, his text provided for:
*   Constitutional guarantees for civil liberties like **freedom of religion**.
*   The **abolition of untouchability**.
*   Social rights for women.
*   A system of **reservation of jobs** in government services for members of **Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes**.

To shape India into a complete **Sovereign Democratic Republic**, Babasaheb incorporated the following principles:
1.  Made the Constitution **workable, flexible, and strong** enough to hold the country together in peace and war.
2.  Provided **special safeguards** for minorities and socially/educationally backward classes.
3.  Incorporated the **Right to Constitutional Remedies** to protect Fundamental Rights from infringement by the Centre or State governments.
4.  Advocated for **single citizenship, a single judiciary, and uniformity in fundamental laws** with a strong Centre to maintain territorial integrity and administrative discipline.
5.  Incorporated **Directive Principles** to ensure social and economic democracy and welfare.

sections.title: READINGS
sections.content_md:
The Draft Constitution was discussed by the Constituent Assembly, clause by clause, through three readings:
*   **First Reading:** Started on November 4, 1948.
*   **Second Reading:** Completed on October 17, 1949.
*   **Third and Final Reading:** Completed on **November 26, 1949**.

sections.title: TIME TAKEN
sections.content_md:
It took nearly **three years** for the Constituent Assembly to finally pass the Constitution.

At the time of its signing, the Constitution consisted of **395 Articles and Eight Schedules**.

sections.title: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CONSTITUTION
sections.content_md:
Immediately after the signing, clauses relating to citizenship came into force. This was to enable persons displaced by the partition to register as Indian citizens.

*   The Constitution was **adopted and passed** on **November 26, 1949**.
*   The Constitution as a whole came into force on **January 26, 1950**.
*   With the Constitution's implementation, **C. Rajagopalachari** became the Governor-General, replacing Lord Mountbatten.
*   The **Constituent Assembly became the provisional parliament** until the first General Elections were held in 1951â€“52.
*   **Dr. Rajendra Prasad**, President of the Constituent Assembly, took over as the first **President of the Indian Union**.

sections.title: SIGNIFICANCE OF JANUARY 26
sections.content_md:
[Image: Indian National Flag]

The date January 26 was chosen for the commencement of the Constitution due to its historical importance.

*   At the **Lahore Session** of the Congress in **December 1929**, a resolution was passed declaring **Poorna Swaraj** (Complete Independence) as the objective.
*   **January 26, 1930**, was fixed as the first **Independence Day**, and it was celebrated as such every year until 1947.
*   After India achieved independence on August 15, 1947, **August 15** became the official **Independence Day**.
*   To honour the historical significance of January 26, this date was designated as **Republic Day**.
